caseName: United States v. Sweeney
firm: DOJ-Enrd, Environmental and Natural Resources Division, USDOJ, ENRD, San Francisco Field Office
United States Department of Justice, Environmental and Natural Resources Division
U.S. Department of Justice, Environment & Natural Resources
US Environmental Protection Agency, Region 9 Office of Regional Counsel
party: The San Francisco Bay Conservation and Development Commission

recap_documents.description: ORDER and JUDGMENT signed by Chief District Judge Kimberly J. Mueller on 9/1/2020   in favor of United States of America  against defendants John Donnelly Sweeney and Point Buckler Club, LLC DECLARING as follows:  Defendant Sweeney has violated and r emains in violation of the Clean Water Act, 33 U.S.C. §§ 1311 and 1344; Defendant Point Buckler Club, LLC, has also violated and remains in violation of the Clean Water Act; Appropriate relief for defendants' Clean Water Act violations  will be provided through the remedy to be ordered following a second phase of proceedings; and that Defendants' violations of the Clean Water Act are very serious, in that their construction of a nearly mile-long levee on Point Buckler Island r esulted in the loss of approximately 30 acres of tidal channels and marsh and their chemical, physical, and biological functioning. Any civil penalty award is held in abeyance pending the resolution of the government's request for amandatory injunction to implement restoration of Point Buckler Island and defendants' completion of that restoration. (Coll, A)

caseName: Massapequa Union Free School District v. New York State Board of Regents
firm: NYS Office of the Attorney General, Nassau Regional Office
New York State Office of the Attorney General
Holtzman Vogel Baran Torchinsky & Josefiak PLLC
party: New York State Board of Regents
Massapequa Union Free School District Board of Education

recap_documents.description: MEMORANDUM AND ORDER granting 40 Defendants' Motion to Dismiss. For the reasons stated in the attached Memorandum and Order, the Court grants Defendants' motion to dismiss. First, the Court grants Defendants' motion to dismiss the constitutional separation of powers claims, as well as the First Amendment and Fourteenth Amendment claims, of School District Plaintiffs, School Board Plaintiffs, and Individual Board Member Plaintiffs suing in their official capacity for lack of capacity. Second, the Court grants Defendants' motion to dismiss Plaintiffs' as-applied and facial vagueness claims for failure to state a claim. Third, the Court grants Defendants' motion to dismiss Plaintiffs' overbreadth claims for failure to state a claim and grants Individual Board Member Plaintiffs leave to amend their Complaints to allege specific facts supporting their First Amendment-based overbreadth claims in their personal capacity. Fourth, the Court grants Defendants motion to dismiss Individual Board Member Plaintiffs' First Amendment free speech claims and grants Individual Board Member Plaintiffs in their personal capacity leave to amend their Complaints to allege specific facts supporting their First Amendment free speech claims. Fifth, the Court grants Defendants motion to dismiss Individual Board Member Plaintiffs' federal separation of powers claim and declines to exercise supplemental jurisdiction over Plaintiffs' state separation of powers claim. Any amended complaint must be filed within thirty days of this Memorandum and Order. If an amended complaint is not timely filed, the Court will direct the Clerk of Court to enter judgment and close this case. The Court denies Plaintiffs' motion for a preliminary injunction. Ordered by Judge Margo K. Brodie on 3/27/2025. (MMB, EPM) Modified on 3/27/2025 (DLMP). (Entered: 03/27/2025)

recap_documents.description: REPORT AND RECOMMENDATIONS: IT IS ORDERED that 54 MOTION for an Order Directing the Submission of Counsel and Confidential Witness Affidavits, and 66 MOTION for Equitable Relief be DENIED, and that the 61 MOTION for Judicial Notice is GRANTED IN PART and DENIED IN PART. IT IS FURTHER RECOMMENDED that 59 MOTION to Dismiss be GRANTED and that Plaintiffs' claims against all Defendants be DISMISSED WITH PREJUDICE, in their entirety. Objections to R&R due by 10/15/2024. Signed by Magistrate Judge Kayla D McClusky on 9/30/2024. (crt,Leday, A) Modified on 10/3/2024 to edit text (Leday, A). (Entered: 09/30/2024)

caseName: Jinan Yipin Corporation, Ltd. v. United States
court: United States Court of International Trade

recap_documents.description: Order entered on 9/26/2011 Slip Op. 11-119, Sustaining in part U. S. Department of Commerce's remand determination in tenth administrative review of antidumping duty order covering fresh garlic from the People's Republic of China. ORDERED t hat this matter is remanded to the U.S. Dept. of Commerce. ORDERED that the remand results shall be filed no later than 12/30/2011. Comments shall be filed no later than 2/13/2012. Deft's response to comments shall be filed no later than 2/28/2012. Replies to Deft's response to comments shall be filed no later than 3/14/2012. (related document(s) 73 ).(Benbow, Troy)
